elements.content: In this work a rigid asymmetrical tricarboxylate ligand p-terphenyl-3,4″,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3L) has been employed, and a unique heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide microporous luminescent metal–organic framework (MOF) {[Ba3La0.5(μ3-L)2.5(H2O)3(DMF)]·(3DMF)} n (1·3DMF) (DMF = dimethylformamide) has been isolated under solvothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis demonstrates that 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivity can be observed in 1, which are further bridged via rigid terphenyl backbones of L3–, forming a unique I 2 O 1-type microporous luminescent framework. A 1D microporous channel with dimensionality of 9.151(3) Å × 10.098(1) Å can be observed along the crystallographic a axis. PXRD patterns have been investigated indicating pure phases of 1. The luminescence explorations demonstrated that 1 exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for Al3+ over other cations with high quenching efficiency K sv value of 1.445 × 104 L·mol–1 and low detection limit (1.11 μM (S/N = 3)). Meanwhile 1 also exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for MnO4 – over other anions with quenching efficiency K sv = 7.73 × 103 L·mol–1 and low detection limit (0.28 μM (S/N = 3)). It is noted that, when different concentrations of MnO4 – solutions (0.5 to 100 μM) were dropped into the suspension of 1, the bright blue luminescence of the suspension observed under UV light can gradually change into pink color, indicating visually luminescent sensing, which makes the detection process of MnO4 – more convenient in practical. The result also reveals that 1 represents the first example of bifunctional heterometallic alkaline earth-lanthanide MOF-based luminescent probes for selectively detecting Al3+ and MnO4 – in the water solutions.

The result also reveals that 1 represents the first example of bifunctional heterometallic alkaline earth-lanthanide MOF-based luminescent probes for selectively detecting Al3+ and MnO4 - in the water solutions.

elements.content: Nowadays, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) assembled by organic ligands and central metal ions or metal clusters have been extensively investigated because of their appealing structural motifs and unique applications in gas storage and luminescence, magnetism, separation/absorption, and industrial catalysis. Among these MOFs, luminescent metal–organic frameworks have received great interest because they can be applied in the selective and sensitive detection of environmental pollutants, which can further protect human health and the environment from harm by these pollutants. The tunable channel size, good structural stability, and large surface area of luminescent MOFs make these coordination materials have a competitive advantage over other luminescent materials because more analytes can effectively interact with channel surface areas of MOFs, which ultimately can improve the rate of luminescent response, decrease the fluorescent-detection limit, and improve the detection sensitivity. On the other hand, recently the rational design and construction of inorganic–organic hybrid coordination materials has become one of the most appealing chemical research areas. The attractive object is justified not only by their unique structural diversity of beautiful architectures but also by their appealing application as functional materials. An inherent structural feature of such hybrid materials is that they can combine the flexibility of organic ligands with the rigidity of inorganic frameworks. As illustrated in the previous literature, for these hybrid materials, the I m O n symbol has been defined on the basis of the dimensionality (m, n) of inorganic (I) and organic (O) connectivities. As for the inorganic connectivity, these hybrid materials possess higher dimensionality (I 1 O n , I 2 O n , and especially I 3 O n ), and they are expected to have enhanced thermal, physical, and chemical properties because of cooperative interactions between metal centers via bridging oxygen atoms and good structural stability of M–O–M linkages. For instance, recently Kitagawa and co-workers also reported an alkaline earth I 3 O 0-type MOF: [Ba2TMA­(NO3)­(DMF)], which contains the unique 3D inorganic Ba–O–Ba connectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) assembled by organic ligands and central metal ions or metal clusters have been extensively investigated because of their appealing structural motifs and unique applications in gas storage and luminescence, magnetism, separation/absorption, and industrial catalysis. Among these MOFs, luminescent metal-organic frameworks have received great interest because they can be applied in the selective and sensitive detection of environmental pollutants, which can further protect human health and the environment from harm by these pollutants. The tunable channel size, good structural stability, and large surface area of luminescent MOFs make these coordination materials have a competitive advantage over other luminescent materials because more analytes can effectively interact with channel surface areas of MOFs, which ultimately can improve the rate of luminescent response, decrease the fluorescent-detection limit, and improve the detection sensitivity. On the other hand, recently the rational design and construction of inorganic-organic hybrid coordination materials has become one of the most appealing chemical research areas. The attractive object is justified not only by their unique structural diversity of beautiful architectures but also by their appealing application as functional materials. An inherent structural feature of such hybrid materials is that they can combine the flexibility of organic ligands with the rigidity of inorganic frameworks. As illustrated in the previous literature, for these hybrid materials, the I  m  O  n  symbol has been defined on the basis of the dimensionality (m, n) of inorganic (I) and organic (O) connectivities. As for the inorganic connectivity, these hybrid materials possess higher dimensionality (I 1 O  n , I 2 O  n , and especially I 3 O  n ), and they are expected to have enhanced thermal, physical, and chemical properties because of cooperative interactions between metal centers via bridging oxygen atoms and good structural stability of M-O-M linkages. For instance, recently Kitagawa and co-workers also reported an alkaline earth I 3 O 0-type MOF: [Ba2TMA(NO3)(DMF)], which contains the unique 3D inorganic Ba-O-Ba connectivity.

elements.content: Aluminum, a group 3 metal, is the most abundant metal element on the crust of the earth. It is well-known that aluminum is extensively used in our daily life and is also one important metal element applied in industry production. However, Al3+ is toxic and environmentally harmful. Due to the frequent use of aluminum vessels and foil, the risk of Al3+ ions absorption by the human body is increasing. For example, the iron-binding protein can carry Al3+ ions to enter the brain, which can further hurt the central nervous system. Al3+ has been implicated as the fatal factor in Alzheimer’s disease, and it also prevents plant growth on acid grounds. Thus, it is urgent for the development of selective and sensitive Al3+ chemsensors. In comparison with other metal ions, only limited examples of Al3+ luminescent sensors have been reported so far. Different analytical methods such as atomic absorption spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and synchrotron radiation X-ray spectrometry have been applied for Al3+ detection. However, these analytical methods are often restricted by complicated sample preparation, sophisticated instruments, and high cost. Therefore, it is important to develop a simple and sensitive method for Al3+ detection.

It is well-known that aluminum is extensively used in our daily life and is also one important metal element applied in industry production. However, Al3+ is toxic and environmentally harmful. Due to the frequent use of aluminum vessels and foil, the risk of Al3+ ions absorption by the human body is increasing. For example, the iron-binding protein can carry Al3+ ions to enter the brain, which can further hurt the central nervous system. Al3+ has been implicated as the fatal factor in Alzheimer's disease, and it also prevents plant growth on acid grounds. Thus, it is urgent for the development of selective and sensitive Al3+ chemsensors. In comparison with other metal ions, only limited examples of Al3+ luminescent sensors have been reported so far. Different analytical methods such as atomic absorption spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and synchrotron radiation X-ray spectrometry have been applied for Al3+ detection. However, these analytical methods are often restricted by complicated sample preparation, sophisticated instruments, and high cost. Therefore, it is important to develop a simple and sensitive method for Al3+ detection.

elements.content: On the other hand, along with the industrialization rapid development, anion pollutants also have become a more serious environmental problem. As for anion pollutants, MnO4 – is the most commonly used strong oxidant in both laboratory and industrial applications. MnO4 – has received great attention because it can cause severe damage to human health and the environment, which is a worldwide problem that is listed as a priority by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. An excess of MnO4 – is harmful to human health, leading to deformity. For example, MnO4 – can lead to severe respiratory tract harm and many adverse effect after inhalation. Besides, MnO4 – in water bodies can also be adsorbed on solid substances and be present in sediments. Several analytical techniques have been used for the detection of MnO4 –, e.g., electrochemistry, ion chromatography, atomic absorption spectrometry, spectrophotometry, flow injection with fluorescence determination, and so on. However, those methods still have some limits, and the determination process of MnO4 – is complicated and time-costing; additionally some techniques have a relatively narrow detection linear range. The exploration of developing new materials for efficient detection of MnO4 – anions from wastewater is also extremely useful.

As for anion pollutants, MnO4 - is the most commonly used strong oxidant in both laboratory and industrial applications. MnO4 - has received great attention because it can cause severe damage to human health and the environment, which is a worldwide problem that is listed as a priority by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. An excess of MnO4 - is harmful to human health, leading to deformity. For example, MnO4 - can lead to severe respiratory tract harm and many adverse effect after inhalation. Besides, MnO4 - in water bodies can also be adsorbed on solid substances and be present in sediments. Several analytical techniques have been used for the detection of MnO4 -, e.g., electrochemistry, ion chromatography, atomic absorption spectrometry, spectrophotometry, flow injection with fluorescence determination, and so on. However, those methods still have some limits, and the determination process of MnO4 - is complicated and time-costing; additionally some techniques have a relatively narrow detection linear range. The exploration of developing new materials for efficient detection of MnO4 - anions from wastewater is also extremely useful.

elements.content: In general, it is well-known that the inner nature of organic ligands and central metal ions or metal clusters, especially that of organic ligands, can significantly tune desired structural motifs and functional properties of the final materials. As for the previously reported luminescent MOF-based sensors, alkaline earth and lanthanide coordination frameworks with π-electron-rich, aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have received great interest based on three points: (1) Aromatic polycarboxylate ligands are extensively employed as bridging linkers in the preparation of MOFs because of their excellent sterical rigidity and chemical stability. However, the employment of asymmetrical polycarboxylates containing large, rigid terphenyl aromatic backbones to construct these porous MOFs is still relatively rare. (2) π-Electron-rich aromatic ligands also facilitate the construction of MOFs with excellent fluorescent properties. Additionally the introduction of electronic-rich aromatic ligands can efficiently improve luminescent-sensing performances. (3) Considering the large radius, rich coordination geometries, and coordination numbers of alkaline earth and lanthanide ions, there exists great potential in the design and preparation of these novel alkaline earth or lanthanide luminescent MOFs. However, to date, only limited examples about heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide MOFs luminescent sensors are reported. We are interested in the synthesis of these metal–organic frameworks with appealing functional properties and intriguing structural motifs. In this work a rigid asymmetrical tricarboxylate ligand p-terphenyl-3,4″,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3L) has been employed (), and a unique heterometallic BaII–LaIII I 2 O 1-type microporous coordination polymer {[Ba3La0.5(μ3-L)2.5(H2O)3(DMF)]·(3DMF)} n (1·3DMF) has been isolated under solvothermal conditions. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns have been investigated, indicating pure phases of 1. Because the synthesized Ba–La complex is neutral, it is expected that the luminescence change would be caused by both cation and anion in the analytes. 1 exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for Al3+ over other cations with a high quenching efficiency K sv value of 1.445 × 104 L·mol–1 and low detection limit (1.11 μM (S/N = 3)). Meanwhile 1 also exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for MnO4 – over other anions with a high quenching efficiency K sv = 7.73 × 103 L·mol–1 and low detection limit (0.28 μM (S/N = 3)). To the best of our knowledge, the application of heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide MOFs as bifunctional fluorescent probes for effective detection of Al3+ and MnO4 – in the water solutions has never been reported. The luminescence explorations also reveals that 1 represents the first example of bifunctional heterometallic BaII–LaIII MOF-based luminescent probes for selectively detecting Al3+ and MnO4 – in the water solutions.

elements.content: H3L was prepared through literature synthetic precedures. Deionized water was used as the solvent in this work. All the other chemical products were commercially available and directly used without further purification. PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to determine carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen elemental microanalyses. Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer instrument (Cu Kα radiation) was used to perform powder X-ray diffraction analysis. NETZSCH TG 209 instrument (10 °C min–1 heating rate) was used to perform thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer instrument was used to investigate solid-state fluorescent spectra, and a helical xenon-arc lamp was used as light source. Al3+ quantitative analysis was analyzed on the X7 Series inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Thermo Electron Corporation, U.S.A.). Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer instrument (Agilent Technologies) was used to investigate photoluminescence sensing experiments, and it was equipped with a plotter unit and had a quartz cell (1 cm × 1 cm) in the phosphorescence mode.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General remarks

H3L was prepared through literature synthetic precedures. Deionized water was used as the solvent in this work. All the other chemical products were commercially available and directly used without further purification. PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to determine carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen elemental microanalyses. Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer instrument (Cu Kα radiation) was used to perform powder X-ray diffraction analysis. NETZSCH TG 209 instrument (10 °C min-1 heating rate) was used to perform thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer instrument was used to investigate solid-state fluorescent spectra, and a helical xenon-arc lamp was used as light source. Al3+ quantitative analysis was analyzed on the X7 Series inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Thermo Electron Corporation, U.S.A.). Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer instrument (Agilent Technologies) was used to investigate photoluminescence sensing experiments, and it was equipped with a plotter unit and had a quartz cell (1 cm × 1 cm) in the phosphorescence mode.

elements.content: 3,5-Dimethylphenylboronic acid (2.00 g, 9.43 mmol), 4-bromo-4′-methylbiphenyl (1.56 g, 10.4 mmol), ethanol (30 mL), toluene (40 mL), and 2 M aqueous Na2CO3 (30 mL) were mixed into a pressure vessel, which was equipped with a stirring apparatus. The mixed solutions were sparged with nitrogen gas for 15 min. Pd­(PPh3)4 was also injected into mixed solutions, and then the seal for the pressure vessel was performed. The mixed solutions were heated at 85 °C for 18 h. When reaction solutions were cooled to ambient temperature, 200 mL of 1,1′-oxybis-ethane was injected. The separation of aqueous layers and organic layers was performed, and aqueous layers were extracted with 3 × 100 mL of 1,1′-oxybis-ethane. Then these organic layers could be combined and desiccated by anhydrous Na2SO4. Further, the filtration of organic layers was performed, and the removal of resulting solvent was also performed through reduced-pressure distillation. The residues were recrystallized from the mixtures of CH2Cl2/n-hexane at zero degrees to provide a white solid 3,4″,5-trimethyl-para-terphenyl (1.73 g, yield 67.4%).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of p-terphenyl-3,4",5-tricarboxylic acid (H3L)

3,5-Dimethylphenylboronic acid (2.00 g, 9.43 mmol), 4-bromo-4'-methylbiphenyl (1.56 g, 10.4 mmol), ethanol (30 mL), toluene (40 mL), and 2 M aqueous Na2CO3 (30 mL) were mixed into a pressure vessel, which was equipped with a stirring apparatus. The mixed solutions were sparged with nitrogen gas for 15 min. Pd(PPh3)4 was also injected into mixed solutions, and then the seal for the pressure vessel was performed. The mixed solutions were heated at 85 °C for 18 h. When reaction solutions were cooled to ambient temperature, 200 mL of 1,1'-oxybis-ethane was injected. The separation of aqueous layers and organic layers was performed, and aqueous layers were extracted with 3 × 100 mL of 1,1'-oxybis-ethane. Then these organic layers could be combined and desiccated by anhydrous Na2SO4. Further, the filtration of organic layers was performed, and the removal of resulting solvent was also performed through reduced-pressure distillation. The residues were recrystallized from the mixtures of CH2Cl2/n-hexane at zero degrees to provide a white solid 3,4",5-trimethyl-para-terphenyl (1.73 g, yield 67.4%).

elements.content: 3,4″,5-Trimethyl-para-terphenyl (0.5 g, 1.8 mmol), KMnO4 (0.87 g, 5.5 mmol), pyridine (20 mL), and deionized water (20 mL) were mixed into a round-bottomed flask. The electric stirring apparatus was also equipped. Then the mixed reaction solutions were stirred and refluxed for 3 days. At this stage additional aliquots of KMnO4 (16 × 0.44 g, 5.5 mmol) were also added. The reaction mixtures were cooled to ambient temperature and were further filtered through a plug of Celite. The evaporation of the filtrate was performed, and 100 mL of deionized water was used to dissolve the residue. Insoluble solid was filtrated; the filtrate was acidified with concentrated hydrochloride acid. White precipitates were isolated after filtration, washed by deionized water, and desiccated in vacuum condition to provide H3L (0.76 g, yield 65.3%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, [D6]­DMSO): d = 13.26 (br, 3H), 8.52–8.46 (m, 3H), 8.10–8.05 (m, 2H), 7.94–7.86 (m, 6H). Anal. calcd for C21H14O6: C, 69.61; H, 3.89. Found: C, 69.85; H, 4.16.

elements.content: A mixture of Ba­(NO3)2 (31.36 mg, 0.12 mmol), La­(NO3)3·6H2O (8.6 mg, 0.02 mmol), and H3L (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was vigorously stirred for half an hour in H2O (5 mL) and DMF (5 mL), and then HNO3 (30 μL, 2 M) was injected into the reaction system. The mixed reaction solutions were added into a Teflon vessel in a stainless steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 12 h, and then automatically cooled to 25 °C during the period of 72 h. The resulting block-shaped colorless single crystals were washed thoroughly with 1,1′-oxybis-ethane and deionized water. Yield: 41% based on H3L. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C65.5H59.5Ba3La0.5N4O21: C 45.74, H 3.49, N 3.26; found: C 45.95, H 3.81, N 3.59. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3400­(br), 1640­(m), 1580­(m), 1530­(m), 1438­(m), 1410­(m), 1360­(m), 1015­(m), 945­(w), 840­(w), 780(s), 705 (w), 650­(w), and 505­(w). Ion detection was performed on the desolvated Ba–La complex 1. A sample of 1·3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba–La complex. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C55.5H39.5Ba3La0.5N2O18.5: C 44.09, H 2.63, N 1.85; found: C 44.36, H 2.85, N 1.97. The PXRD result of the desolvated Ba–La complex 1 also was determined (Figure S2), demonstrating that the microporous framework is retained after guest solvent molecules are removed.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Ba3La0.5(μ3-L)2.5(H2O)3(DMF)]⋅(3DMF)} n  (1⋅3DMF)

A mixture of Ba(NO3)2 (31.36 mg, 0.12 mmol), La(NO3)3⋅6H2O (8.6 mg, 0.02 mmol), and H3L (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was vigorously stirred for half an hour in H2O (5 mL) and DMF (5 mL), and then HNO3 (30 μL, 2 M) was injected into the reaction system. The mixed reaction solutions were added into a Teflon vessel in a stainless steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 12 h, and then automatically cooled to 25 °C during the period of 72 h. The resulting block-shaped colorless single crystals were washed thoroughly with 1,1'-oxybis-ethane and deionized water. Yield: 41% based on H3L. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C65.5H59.5Ba3La0.5N4O21: C 45.74, H 3.49, N 3.26; found: C 45.95, H 3.81, N 3.59. FT-IR data (cm-1): 3400(br), 1640(m), 1580(m), 1530(m), 1438(m), 1410(m), 1360(m), 1015(m), 945(w), 840(w), 780(s), 705 (w), 650(w), and 505(w). Ion detection was performed on the desolvated Ba-La complex 1. A sample of 1⋅3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba-La complex. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C55.5H39.5Ba3La0.5N2O18.5: C 44.09, H 2.63, N 1.85; found: C 44.36, H 2.85, N 1.97. The PXRD result of the desolvated Ba-La complex 1 also was determined (Figure S2), demonstrating that the microporous framework is retained after guest solvent molecules are removed.

elements.content: The Bruker SMART 1000 charge-coupled device (CCD) diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was used to determine single-crystal diffraction intensities for 1·3DMF. The ω–φ scan technique was applied using Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections. Direct techniques were used to solve the crystal structure. Full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 and SHELXS-97 programs were also used to refine the structure. Anisotropic thermal parameters were allocated to all non-hydrogen atoms. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were used, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were allocated from difference maps and then refined with isotropic temperature factors. Hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were allocated geometrically, and isotropic thermal parameters of these atoms are 1.2 times than those of the attached carbon atoms. Because guest solvent molecules are highly disordered and cannot be precisely allocated using X-ray crystallography, the SQUEEZE model has been applied to remove these guest solvent molecules in the void spaces. Guest solvent molecules were further analyzed by elemental analysis and TG analysis. CCDC-1438184 (1·3DMF) represents the supplementary crystallographic data for this work. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif and can be seen in the Supporting Information. The crystallographic data and refinement details for 1·3DMF are listed in , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are summarized in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The Bruker SMART 1000 charge-coupled device (CCD) diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was used to determine single-crystal diffraction intensities for 1⋅3DMF. The ω-φ scan technique was applied using Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections. Direct techniques were used to solve the crystal structure. Full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 and SHELXS-97 programs were also used to refine the structure. Anisotropic thermal parameters were allocated to all non-hydrogen atoms. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were used, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were allocated from difference maps and then refined with isotropic temperature factors. Hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were allocated geometrically, and isotropic thermal parameters of these atoms are 1.2 times than those of the attached carbon atoms. Because guest solvent molecules are highly disordered and cannot be precisely allocated using X-ray crystallography, the SQUEEZE model has been applied to remove these guest solvent molecules in the void spaces. Guest solvent molecules were further analyzed by elemental analysis and TG analysis. CCDC-1438184 (1⋅3DMF) represents the supplementary crystallographic data for this work. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif and can be seen in the Supporting Information. The crystallographic data and refinement details for 1⋅3DMF are listed in , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are summarized in Table S1.

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis demonstrates that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2 space group. In 1, the fundamental unit contains three crystallographically independent BaII ions (Ba1, Ba2, Ba3), half LaIII ions (La1), 2.5 full deprotonated L3– ligands, one terminal-coordinated DMF, one bridging water (O13), and two terminal-coordinated water solvent molecules (O14 and O23) (). As shown in , the three full deprotonated L3– ligands adopt three different coordination modes: one L3– ligand adopts μ10-η1, η2, η1, η2, η2, η2 coordination mode (a), the second L3– ligand adopts μ8-η1, η2, η1, η2, η2 coordination mode (b), and the third L3– ligand adopts μ10-η2, η2, η1, η2, η1, η2 coordination mode (c). As shown in , all the central BaII and LaIII ions adopt seven- and eight-coordinated coordination geometries. Ba1 is seven-coordinated by six oxygen atoms (O7, O8, O11, O12, O2, and O6) from four carboxylic groups and one bridging water molecule (O13) (a). Ba2 is eight-coordinated by seven oxygen atoms (O3, O4, O3A, O7, O8, O10, and O11) from five carboxylic groups and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O14) (b). Ba3 is also eight-coordinated by seven oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5, O6, O15, O16, and O21) from five carboxylic groups and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O23) (c). Eight-coordinated La1 is coordinated by eight oxyen atoms (O1, O1A, O15, O15A, O21, O21A, O22, and O22A) from five carboxylic groups (d). All the Ba–O and La–O bond distances vary from 2.628 to 2.948 Å, which are close to the previously reported distances.

elements.content: In compound 1, these neighboring BaII and LaIII ions are interlinked via carboxylate groups forming an infinite 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivity of 1 (). Further these neighboring 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivities are interlinked via terphenyl groups forming a 3D microporous heterometallic BaII–LaIII metal–organic framework of 1. As shown in , 1D microporous channel with dimensionality of 9.151(3) Å × 10.098(1) Å can be observed along the crystallographic a axis (defined by the atom-to-atom distance of the corner metal ions). A PLATON program analysis demonstrates that there is ∼27.0% of the crystal volume (1775.4 Å3 potential solvent areas) accessible to guest molecules. The large volume value can be compared with those previously reported microporous MOFs. Rao and co-workers also elaborate the typical examples of inorganic–organic hybrid materials. As is illustrated in the previous literature and is seen from these kinds of hybrid materials, there are only a few microporous coordination frameworks with 2-D or 3-D inorganic connectivity. 1 also represents a novel example of I 2 O 1-type inorganic–organic microporous heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide 3D microporous framework.

elements.content: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra demonstrate typical absorption peaks for coordinated water molecules and L3– ligand molecules. 1 exhibits broad and medium bands ca. 3400 cm–1, which can be assigned as the characteristic absorption peak of coordinated water molecules in the coordination framework. The absence of strong absorption bands ca. 1700 cm–1 reveals complete deprotonation of the carboxylic groups. For 1, the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups are observed in the ranges of 1360–1438 and 1530–1640 cm–1, respectively. All the FT-IR characteristic absorption peaks agree well with the single-crystal X-ray result.

elements.content: To determine the thermo-stability of nanoporous structures, we investigated the thermal decomposition process of 1·3DMF. As shown in Figure S1, thermal decomposition of 1·3DMF exhibits three weight loss processes, and it is finally composed into the corresponding oxides. The first weight loss process of 13.25% varying from 25 to 150 °C is due to the loss of three lattice DMF molecules (calcd 12.74%). Subsequently, the second weight loss process of 7.05% varies from 160 to 350 °C, corresponding to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule and three coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.39%). In the third weight loss process, the complex is finally decomposed into BaO and La2O3 with a residual weight of 36.53% (calcd 36.21%). A sample of 1·3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba–La complex 1. To determine the thermal stability of 1, it was heated under different temperatures for 6 h, and then corresponding PXRD patterns of these samples after heating were investigated. As shown in Figure S2, the framework began to collapse when all the coordinated DMF and coordinated water molecules are removed above 160 °C.

Subsequently, the second weight loss process of 7.05% varies from 160 to 350 °C, corresponding to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule and three coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.39%). In the third weight loss process, the complex is finally decomposed into BaO and La2O3 with a residual weight of 36.53% (calcd 36.21%). A sample of 1⋅3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba-La complex 1. To determine the thermal stability of 1, it was heated under different temperatures for 6 h, and then corresponding PXRD patterns of these samples after heating were investigated. As shown in Figure S2, the framework began to collapse when all the coordinated DMF and coordinated water molecules are removed above 160 °C.

elements.content: Aromatic organic ligands and their coordination polymers have received great attention for their unique photoluminescent properties and their great application prospects as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because the structural motifs of these organic linkers and inorganic–organic coordination polymers can be designed and tuned, the fluorescent emission strength and wavelength of these materials can be deliberately adjusted. Through the rational incorporation of diverse metal centers (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers) and different conjugated aromatic organic linkers, it is a quite efficient synthetic method for constructing novel types of photoluminescent coordination materials. It is well-known that a double bond consisting of σ and π bonds and the emission peaks of aromatic organic linkers are generally assigned as π* → n or π → π* transitions. The H3L ligand contains large, rigid terphenyl aromatic backbones and is expected to generate strong photoluminescence emissions. Previous investigations also confirm that coordination frameworks can further effectively change the emission wavelength and strength of aromatic organic linkers through rational incorporation of different central metal ions (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers). Thus, we are greatly motivated to determine photoluminescent properties of free H3L ligand and 1 in the solid state and in aqueous solution, respectively. As shown in Figure S3, at ambient temperature, the free H3L ligand has strong luminescent emissions in the solid state, which exhibits the broad emission peak with a maximum at 445 nm (λex = 370 nm), while its emission spectrum in water solutions is at 374 nm. For the H3L ligand the strong fluorescent emissions can be ascribed to large aromatic terphenyl chromospheres, and the observed strong emission bands can be assigned as π–π* transition. In comparison with that of free H3L ligand, upon excitation at 370 nm, the 3D metal–organic framework 1 exhibits strong emission bands with a maximum around 410 nm. On the other hand, when the crystalline materials were ground into powder samples and suspended in the water solutions, 1 exhibits a strong luminescent emission peak with maximum at 374 nm upon excitation at 340 nm, which can be assigned to the luminescence from intraligand emission because similar luminescent bands can be observed for the free H3L ligand in the water solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent properties of 1 

Aromatic organic ligands and their coordination polymers have received great attention for their unique photoluminescent properties and their great application prospects as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because the structural motifs of these organic linkers and inorganic-organic coordination polymers can be designed and tuned, the fluorescent emission strength and wavelength of these materials can be deliberately adjusted. Through the rational incorporation of diverse metal centers (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers) and different conjugated aromatic organic linkers, it is a quite efficient synthetic method for constructing novel types of photoluminescent coordination materials. It is well-known that a double bond consisting of σ and π bonds and the emission peaks of aromatic organic linkers are generally assigned as π* → n or π → π* transitions. The H3L ligand contains large, rigid terphenyl aromatic backbones and is expected to generate strong photoluminescence emissions. Previous investigations also confirm that coordination frameworks can further effectively change the emission wavelength and strength of aromatic organic linkers through rational incorporation of different central metal ions (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers). Thus, we are greatly motivated to determine photoluminescent properties of free H3L ligand and 1 in the solid state and in aqueous solution, respectively. As shown in Figure S3, at ambient temperature, the free H3L ligand has strong luminescent emissions in the solid state, which exhibits the broad emission peak with a maximum at 445 nm (λex = 370 nm), while its emission spectrum in water solutions is at 374 nm. For the H3L ligand the strong fluorescent emissions can be ascribed to large aromatic terphenyl chromospheres, and the observed strong emission bands can be assigned as π-π* transition. In comparison with that of free H3L ligand, upon excitation at 370 nm, the 3D metal-organic framework 1 exhibits strong emission bands with a maximum around 410 nm. On the other hand, when the crystalline materials were ground into powder samples and suspended in the water solutions, 1 exhibits a strong luminescent emission peak with maximum at 374 nm upon excitation at 340 nm, which can be assigned to the luminescence from intraligand emission because similar luminescent bands can be observed for the free H3L ligand in the water solutions.

elements.content: The water stability of 1 was also investigated, and the solid-state samples were suspended in the water solutions for 12 h; then water solutions were filtrated and solid-state samples were desiccated by the vacuum oven. Then solid-state samples were characterized by PXRD patterns. As shown in b, PXRD patterns of the desolvated Ba–La complex suspended in the water solutions agree well with these calculated patterns simulated from single-crystal X-ray data. The result indicates that the metal–organic framework structure of 1 is unchangeable and can remain stable in the water solutions. On the other hand, as shown in a, the fluorescent bands are almost unchanged, indicating 1 can have good fluorescent stability for 12 h. The good fluorescent stability results from good solvent stability and dispersibility of compound 1 in aqueous solutions. Therefore, 1 can be employed as a prominent candidate for fluorescent detection in aqueous solutions.

elements.content: Among various metal ions, Al3+ is dangerous because of its high carcinogenicity and toxicity. It is extensively employed in many fields, such as military affairs, agriculture, industry, etc. Furthermore, toxic aluminum is easily absorbed and accumulated in many plants, organisms, and life system. This can lead to many severe diseases and even the formation of cancers. Considering the great risks correlated with human health and environment, qualitatively and quantitatively detecting aluminum is significantly important. Recently, luminescent sensors have been seen as compelling and promising techniques for sensing diverse metal ions because they provide a simple, highly sensitive, highly selective, precise, and economical way for real-time monitoring without any sample pretreatment together with the advantages of high spatial and time resolution.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent sensing properties of Al3+ for 1 

Among various metal ions, Al3+ is dangerous because of its high carcinogenicity and toxicity. It is extensively employed in many fields, such as military affairs, agriculture, industry, etc. Furthermore, toxic aluminum is easily absorbed and accumulated in many plants, organisms, and life system. This can lead to many severe diseases and even the formation of cancers. Considering the great risks correlated with human health and environment, qualitatively and quantitatively detecting aluminum is significantly important. Recently, luminescent sensors have been seen as compelling and promising techniques for sensing diverse metal ions because they provide a simple, highly sensitive, highly selective, precise, and economical way for real-time monitoring without any sample pretreatment together with the advantages of high spatial and time resolution.

elements.content: In this work, the samples of 1 were employed as luminescent probes and were investigated for the sensing of diverse metal ions, because 1 can exhibit strong visible blue light when excited by ultraviolet light. For investigating different fluorescent responses to metal ions, the crystalline materials of 1 were ground into powder samples and added as the suspension into the aqueous solutions containing different chloride metal salt solutions of the same concentration (10–4 M) of Mg2+, Li+, Na+, K+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Ni2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Hg2+, and Zn2+ in neutral conditions. As shown in a, only Al3+ ions gave significant fluorescence-quenching effect, while other metal ions only have a slight effect on the fluorescent intensity. PXRD patterns for 1–Al3+ were also determined (Figure S6b) and agrees well with the simulated PXRD patterns based on single-crystal structures, demonstrating that the microporous framework of 1 remains unchangeable. The result indicates 1 has highly selective recognition of Al3+ ions in water solutions. Therefore, 1 can be employed as an excellent candidate material for selective luminescent detection of Al3+ ions.

elements.content: Generally, wastewater contains more than one kind of metal ion pollutant, and thus, it is important to measure the interference of mixed metal ions on the fluorescent emissions of 1. The experiment details are listed as follows: 0.4 mL of AlCl3 (10–3 M) and 0.4 mL of other metal ion solutions (10–2 M) were injected into 3.2 mL of water solutions containing the suspension of 1, respectively. The final concentration of Al3+ is 10–4 M, while the concentration of other metal ions is 10–3 M in the mixed aqua solutions. The luminescence emissions of the resulting mixed solutions, simultaneously containing Al3+ and other metal ions, were determined at once. As shown in Figure S4, it is evident that only Al3+ has a significant effect on the luminescence intensity. The selective detection of Al3+ ions is not affected by other metal ions such as Mg2+, Li+, K+, Na+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Ni2+, Ba2+, Hg2+, and Zn2+, demonstrating that 1 can selectively detect Al3+ ions among the listed metal ions.

elements.content: Additionally, to investigate the fluorescent-detection limit of 1 as a luminescent probe for Al3+, as shown in b, a series of suspensions of 1–Al3+ (5–60 μM) in the aqueous solutions has been prepared by injecting different concentrations of Al3+ into aqueous solutions containing the suspension of 1. It can be seen that, when Al3+ concentrations gradually increase, the fluorescent intensity of 1 gradually decreases. As shown in c and d, the fluorescent intensity linearly decreases with Al3+concentration varying from 5 to 60 μM. The fluorescent detection limit of 1 for Al3+ is calculated by the following equation: detection limit = 3σ/k (k represents the slope between the fluorescent intensity vs log Al3+; σ represents the standard deviation of blank determination). To further investigate the correlation between quenching result and Al3+ concentration, the linear fluorescent intensity vs Al3+ concentration plot was made (d), which can be fitted through the equation I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Al3+] (I 0 and I are the fluorescent intensities of 1 before and after adding Al3+, respectively; K sv is the quenching rate constant; and [Al3+] represents the concentration of Al3+). The K sv value is calculated to be 1.445 × 104 L·mol–1, and a low detection limit (0.19 μM (S/N = 3)) indicates a high quenching-efficiency constant of Al3+ in the emission of 1. Further, the recyclable performance of 1 was also investigated; the samples of 1 were added into an aqueous solution of Al3+ to completely form 1–Al3+, and then 1–Al3+ was simply washed with water several times. The results show that the fluorescent intensity of compound 1 can be partially resumed through the simple method of using water to wash the 1–Al3+ sample (Figure S5). As for 1, the discussions were given as follows: (1) PXRD patterns of the initial samples and recovered samples after five cycles of quenching and recovery test are also compared and are almost identical (Figure S6), which indicates high stability of coordination framework 1. (2) Besides intensity change, there is not any emission band shift caused by Al3+. (3) The amount of the uploading Al3+ ions, especially for those recycling experiments (Table S2), has be measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), which is in proportion to the luminescent quenching of 1. (4) The fast and simple regeneration method showed that interactions between 1 and Al3+ ions in the detecting process should be weak. Therefore, we speculate that Al3+ may be diffused into the channels of 1 or attached to the surface of 1 rapidly, and the encapsulated Al3+ ions are responsible for the quenching of the luminescence. To our knowledge, work on these metal–organic frameworks as fluorescent probes for discriminating and sensitively detecting Al3+ pollutants is still quite limited. The luminescence experiments revealed that 1 represents the first example of heterometallic MOF-based fluorescent probes for detecting Al3+, possessing high selectivity and high sensitivity.

Therefore, we speculate that Al3+ may be diffused into the channels of 1 or attached to the surface of 1 rapidly, and the encapsulated Al3+ ions are responsible for the quenching of the luminescence. To our knowledge, work on these metal-organic frameworks as fluorescent probes for discriminating and sensitively detecting Al3+ pollutants is still quite limited. The luminescence experiments revealed that 1 represents the first example of heterometallic MOF-based fluorescent probes for detecting Al3+, possessing high selectivity and high sensitivity.

elements.content: In recent decades water pollution has become a global environmental issue, and considerable research interest has been paid to sensitive detection of pollutants from industrial wastewater. Along with the industrialization rapid development, MnO4 – anions have been widely applied in the field of metal technology, leather tanning, paint manufacturing, wood preservation, and chromium plating. These anion pollutants have received great attention because they can cause severe damage to the environment and human health. In industry, MnO4 – has been widely applied as bleaching agents and disinfectant agents. In the research laboratory, the acidic MnO4 – solution is used as an important oxidation–reduction reagent. The investigation of new materials for efficiently detecting MnO4 – is extremely useful. In this work we also carefully investigate the fluorescent responses for different anions. The crystalline materials of 1 were ground into powder samples and added as the suspension into aqueous solutions containing different sodium salt solutions of the same concentration (10–4 M) of PO4 3–, Cl–, SiF6 2–, CO3 2–, HCO3 2–, BF4 –, NO3 –, Ac–, SCN–, SO4 2–, Br–, I–, F–, IO3 –, BrO3 –, MnO4 –, and ClO4 2– in neutral conditions. As shown in a, only MnO4 – anions gave significant fluorescence-quenching effect, while other anions only have a slight effect on the fluorescent intensity. PXRD patterns of 1–MnO4 – were determined (Figure S7b) and agree well with the simulated PXRD patterns based on single-crystal structures, indicating that the microporous framework of 1 still remains unchangeable. The result indicates that 1 has highly selective detection and specific recognition of MnO4 – anions in aqueous solutions. Therefore, 1 can be employed as an excellent candidate material for selective sensing of MnO4 – anions.

elements.content: Generally, wastewater contains more than one kind of anion pollutant, and thus, it is important to explore the interference of mixed anions on the luminescence emissions of 1. The experiment details are listed as follows: 0.4 mL of KMnO4 (10–3 M) and 0.4 mL of other anion solutions (10–2 M) were injected into 3.2 mL of water solutions containing the suspension of 1, respectively. The final concentration of MnO4 – is 10–4 M, while the concentration of other anions is 10–3 M in the mixed aqua solutions. The luminescence emissions of the resulting mixed solutions, simultaneously containing MnO4 – and other anions, were determined at once. It is also evident that only MnO4 – has a significant effect on the luminescence intensity. This selective detection of MnO4 – anions is not affected by other anions such as SiF6 2–, CO3 2–, HCO3 2–, BF4 –, NO3 –, SCN–, Ac–, SO4 2–, Br–, Cl–, F–, I–, BrO3 –, IO3 –, CrO4 2–, HPO4 2–, and PO4 3–, demonstrating that 1 also can selectively detect MnO4 – anions among the listed anions.

elements.content: Additionally, to explore the fluorescent-detection limit of 1 as a luminescent probe for MnO4 –, as shown in b, a series of suspensions of 1–MnO4 – (0.5–100 μM) has been prepared by injecting different concentrations of MnO4 – into aqueous solutions containing the suspension of 1. It can be seen that, when MnO4 – concentrations gradually increase, the fluorescent intensity of 1 gradually decreases. As shown in a, the luminescence intensity linearly decreases with the concentration of MnO4 – varying from 0.5 to 100 μM. The fluorescent detection limit of 1 for MnO4 – is calculated by the following equation: detection limit = 3σ/k (k represents the slope between the luminescence intensity vs log [MnO4 –]; σ represents the standard deviation of blank determination). To further investigate the correlation between the quenching result and the MnO4 – concentration, the linear luminescence intensity vs MnO4 – concentration plot was made (b), which can be fitted through the equation I 0/I = 1 + K sv[MnO4 –] (I 0 and I are the fluorescent intensities of 1 before and after adding MnO4 –, respectively; K sv is the quenching rate constant; [MnO4 –] represents the concentration of MnO4 –). The K sv value is calculated to be 7.73 × 103 L·mol–1, indicating the high quenching-efficiency constant of MnO4 – in the emission of 1. It is noted that, when different concentrations of MnO4 – solutions (0.5–100 μM) were added into the suspension of 1, the bright blue luminescence of the suspension observed under UV light can gradually change into pink color, visually indicating luminescent sensing, which makes the detection process of MnO4 – more convenient and practical (c). The high quenching efficiency and low detection limit of 0.28 μM (S/N = 3) also represent that 1 can act as visually luminescent probes for discrimination and detection of MnO4 – anions.

elements.content: We also tried to explore the luminescence-response mechanisms; as for 1, the discussions were given as follows: (1) PXRD pattern of 1–MnO4 – was determined (Figure S7b) and agrees well with the simulated PXRD patterns based on the single-crystal structure of 1, indicating that the microporous framework still remains unchangeable. (2) Besides intensity change, there is not an obvious emission band shift caused by MnO4 – (Figure S7a). (3) In the FT-IR spectra of 1–MnO4 –, the emergence of the characteristic adsorption band of MnO4 – at 888 cm–1 confirms that MnO4 – anions exist in the solid sample. Additionally the solid sample of 1 immersed into the MnO4 – aqueous solutions changes from pale yellow to brown,which also confirms that MnO4 – are diffused into the microporous framework of 1 (d). (4) We also attempted to investigate the recyclable performance in the solution of MnO4 –; however, no good recyclable performance for MnO4 – can be observed via simply water washing, which indicates MnO4 – are not simply attached on the solid surface of 1. Because the photoluminescence emission bands of 1 in the aqueous solutions can be ascribed to intraligand transitions, a possible reason for selective luminescence quenching by MnO4 – anions may be that 1 can effectively promote absorption of MnO4 – anions and not of the other anions. As illustrated in the previous literature, if the added analytes could be diffused into the microporous framework of 1 and effectively absorb energy from the excitation light and/or the excited state from the organic linkers, simultaneously reducing the energy transfer to the metal centers, the luminescence emissions of 1 would be substantially reduced. To our knowledge, work on these metal–organic frameworks as fluorescent probes for discriminating and sensitively detecting MnO4 – anion pollutants is still quite limited. Therefore, 1 also represents the scarcely reported novel example of 3D heterometallic metal organic framework as luminescent probes of new visually sensing materials for MnO4 – in the aqueous solutions.

elements.content: Along with the industrialization rapid development, environment pollutants have become a more and more serious social problem; the exploration of developing new materials for efficiently detecting these environment pollutants from wastewater is extremely useful. In this work a rigid asymmetrical tricarboxylate ligand p-terphenyl-3,4″,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3L) was employed; a unique microporous heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide luminescent metal–organic framework {[Ba3La0.5(μ3-L)2.5(H2O)3(DMF)]·(3DMF)} n (1·3DMF) has been isolated under solvothermal conditions. Structural analysis demonstrated that 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivity can be observed in 1, which are further bridged via rigid terphenyl backbones of L3– forming a unique I 2 O 1-type inorganic–organic hybrid microporous heterometallic luminescent framework. 1D microporous channel with dimensionality of 9.151(3) Å × 10.098(1) Å can be observed along the crystallographic a axis. PXRD patterns and solid-state fluorescent properties of 1 have been determined. 1 exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for Al3+ cations over other inorganic cations with high quenching efficiency K sv value of 1.445 × 104 L·mol–1 and low detection limit (1.11 μM (S/N = 3)). Meanwhile 1 also exhibits highly selective and visually sensitive sensing for MnO4 – anions over other anions with high quenching-efficiency constant K sv = 7.73 × 103 L·mol–1 and low fluorescent-detection limit (0.28 μM (S/N = 3)). The high quenching efficiency and selectivity make 1 able to be used as a potential bifunctional luminescence chemosensor for both Al3+ and MnO4 – ions in the aqueous solutions. These results open up the exploration of new aspects of a multifunctional 3D heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide nanoporous framework, which exhibits unique applications in sensitive detecting of these environment pollutants. The result also represents that these π-electron-rich asymmetrical aromatic polycarboxylate linkers have great applications in the synthesis of these novel metal–organic frameworks with intriguing structural motifs and excellent luminescent-sensing properties. On the basis of this work, further design, construction, and functional-properties investigation of microporous metal–organic frameworks based on these π-electron-rich asymmetrical rigid building blocks are also underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Perspectives

Along with the industrialization rapid development, environment pollutants have become a more and more serious social problem; the exploration of developing new materials for efficiently detecting these environment pollutants from wastewater is extremely useful. In this work a rigid asymmetrical tricarboxylate ligand p-terphenyl-3,4",5-tricarboxylic acid (H3L) was employed; a unique microporous heterometallic alkaline earth-lanthanide luminescent metal-organic framework {[Ba3La0.5(μ3-L)2.5(H2O)3(DMF)]⋅(3DMF)} n  (1⋅3DMF) has been isolated under solvothermal conditions. Structural analysis demonstrated that 2D inorganic Ba-O-La connectivity can be observed in 1, which are further bridged via rigid terphenyl backbones of L3- forming a unique I 2 O 1-type inorganic-organic hybrid microporous heterometallic luminescent framework. 1D microporous channel with dimensionality of 9.151(3) Å × 10.098(1) Å can be observed along the crystallographic a axis. PXRD patterns and solid-state fluorescent properties of 1 have been determined. 1 exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing for Al3+ cations over other inorganic cations with high quenching efficiency K sv value of 1.445 × 104 L⋅mol-1 and low detection limit (1.11 μM (S/N = 3)). Meanwhile 1 also exhibits highly selective and visually sensitive sensing for MnO4 - anions over other anions with high quenching-efficiency constant K sv = 7.73 × 103 L⋅mol-1 and low fluorescent-detection limit (0.28 μM (S/N = 3)). The high quenching efficiency and selectivity make 1 able to be used as a potential bifunctional luminescence chemosensor for both Al3+ and MnO4 - ions in the aqueous solutions. These results open up the exploration of new aspects of a multifunctional 3D heterometallic alkaline earth-lanthanide nanoporous framework, which exhibits unique applications in sensitive detecting of these environment pollutants. The result also represents that these π-electron-rich asymmetrical aromatic polycarboxylate linkers have great applications in the synthesis of these novel metal-organic frameworks with intriguing structural motifs and excellent luminescent-sensing properties. On the basis of this work, further design, construction, and functional-properties investigation of microporous metal-organic frameworks based on these π-electron-rich asymmetrical rigid building blocks are also underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
3,5-Dimethylphenylboronic acid (2.00 g, 9.43 mmol), 4-bromo-4′-methylbiphenyl (1.56 g, 10.4 mmol), ethanol (30 mL), toluene (40 mL), and 2 M aqueous Na2CO3 (30 mL) were mixed into a pressure vessel, which was equipped with a stirring apparatus. The mixed solutions were sparged with nitrogen gas for 15 min. Pd­(PPh3)4 was also injected into mixed solutions, and then the seal for the pressure vessel was performed. The mixed solutions were heated at 85 °C for 18 h. When reaction solutions were cooled to ambient temperature, 200 mL of 1,1′-oxybis-ethane was injected. The separation of aqueous layers and organic layers was performed, and aqueous layers were extracted with 3 × 100 mL of 1,1′-oxybis-ethane. Then these organic layers could be combined and desiccated by anhydrous Na2SO4. Further, the filtration of organic layers was performed, and the removal of resulting solvent was also performed through reduced-pressure distillation. The residues were recrystallized from the mixtures of CH2Cl2/n-hexane at zero degrees to provide a white solid 3,4″,5-trimethyl-para-terphenyl (1.73 g, yield 67.4%).

3,4″,5-Trimethyl-para-terphenyl (0.5 g, 1.8 mmol), KMnO4 (0.87 g, 5.5 mmol), pyridine (20 mL), and deionized water (20 mL) were mixed into a round-bottomed flask. The electric stirring apparatus was also equipped. Then the mixed reaction solutions were stirred and refluxed for 3 days. At this stage additional aliquots of KMnO4 (16 × 0.44 g, 5.5 mmol) were also added. The reaction mixtures were cooled to ambient temperature and were further filtered through a plug of Celite. The evaporation of the filtrate was performed, and 100 mL of deionized water was used to dissolve the residue. Insoluble solid was filtrated; the filtrate was acidified with concentrated hydrochloride acid. White precipitates were isolated after filtration, washed by deionized water, and desiccated in vacuum condition to provide H3L (0.76 g, yield 65.3%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, [D6]­DMSO): d = 13.26 (br, 3H), 8.52–8.46 (m, 3H), 8.10–8.05 (m, 2H), 7.94–7.86 (m, 6H). Anal. calcd for C21H14O6: C, 69.61; H, 3.89. Found: C, 69.85; H, 4.16.

Preparation of {[Ba<sub>3</sub>La<sub>0.5</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-L)<sub>2.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>(DMF)]·(3DMF)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1·3DMF</bold>)

A mixture of Ba­(NO3)2 (31.36 mg, 0.12 mmol), La­(NO3)3·6H2O (8.6 mg, 0.02 mmol), and H3L (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was vigorously stirred for half an hour in H2O (5 mL) and DMF (5 mL), and then HNO3 (30 μL, 2 M) was injected into the reaction system. The mixed reaction solutions were added into a Teflon vessel in a stainless steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 12 h, and then automatically cooled to 25 °C during the period of 72 h. The resulting block-shaped colorless single crystals were washed thoroughly with 1,1′-oxybis-ethane and deionized water. Yield: 41% based on H3L. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C65.5H59.5Ba3La0.5N4O21: C 45.74, H 3.49, N 3.26; found: C 45.95, H 3.81, N 3.59. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3400­(br), 1640­(m), 1580­(m), 1530­(m), 1438­(m), 1410­(m), 1360­(m), 1015­(m), 945­(w), 840­(w), 780(s), 705 (w), 650­(w), and 505­(w). Ion detection was performed on the desolvated Ba–La complex 1. A sample of 1·3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba–La complex. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C55.5H39.5Ba3La0.5N2O18.5: C 44.09, H 2.63, N 1.85; found: C 44.36, H 2.85, N 1.97. The PXRD result of the desolvated Ba–La complex 1 also was determined (Figure S2), demonstrating that the microporous framework is retained after guest solvent molecules are removed.

cln_elements.content:
In compound 1, these neighboring BaII and LaIII ions are interlinked via carboxylate groups forming an infinite 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivity of 1 (). Further these neighboring 2D inorganic Ba–O–La connectivities are interlinked via terphenyl groups forming a 3D microporous heterometallic BaII–LaIII metal–organic framework of 1. As shown in , 1D microporous channel with dimensionality of 9.151(3) Å × 10.098(1) Å can be observed along the crystallographic a axis (defined by the atom-to-atom distance of the corner metal ions). A PLATON program analysis demonstrates that there is ∼27.0% of the crystal volume (1775.4 Å3 potential solvent areas) accessible to guest molecules. The large volume value can be compared with those previously reported microporous MOFs. Rao and co-workers also elaborate the typical examples of inorganic–organic hybrid materials. As is illustrated in the previous literature and is seen from these kinds of hybrid materials, there are only a few microporous coordination frameworks with 2-D or 3-D inorganic connectivity. 1 also represents a novel example of I 2 O 1-type inorganic–organic microporous heterometallic alkaline earth–lanthanide 3D microporous framework.

To determine the thermo-stability of nanoporous structures, we investigated the thermal decomposition process of 1·3DMF. As shown in Figure S1, thermal decomposition of 1·3DMF exhibits three weight loss processes, and it is finally composed into the corresponding oxides. The first weight loss process of 13.25% varying from 25 to 150 °C is due to the loss of three lattice DMF molecules (calcd 12.74%). Subsequently, the second weight loss process of 7.05% varies from 160 to 350 °C, corresponding to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule and three coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.39%). In the third weight loss process, the complex is finally decomposed into BaO and La2O3 with a residual weight of 36.53% (calcd 36.21%). A sample of 1·3DMF was heated at 130 °C in the oven for 24 h to afford the desolvated Ba–La complex 1. To determine the thermal stability of 1, it was heated under different temperatures for 6 h, and then corresponding PXRD patterns of these samples after heating were investigated. As shown in Figure S2, the framework began to collapse when all the coordinated DMF and coordinated water molecules are removed above 160 °C.

Photoluminescent properties of <bold>1</bold>

Aromatic organic ligands and their coordination polymers have received great attention for their unique photoluminescent properties and their great application prospects as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because the structural motifs of these organic linkers and inorganic–organic coordination polymers can be designed and tuned, the fluorescent emission strength and wavelength of these materials can be deliberately adjusted. Through the rational incorporation of diverse metal centers (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers) and different conjugated aromatic organic linkers, it is a quite efficient synthetic method for constructing novel types of photoluminescent coordination materials. It is well-known that a double bond consisting of σ and π bonds and the emission peaks of aromatic organic linkers are generally assigned as π* → n or π → π* transitions. The H3L ligand contains large, rigid terphenyl aromatic backbones and is expected to generate strong photoluminescence emissions. Previous investigations also confirm that coordination frameworks can further effectively change the emission wavelength and strength of aromatic organic linkers through rational incorporation of different central metal ions (such as 3d, 4d, or 4f metal centers). Thus, we are greatly motivated to determine photoluminescent properties of free H3L ligand and 1 in the solid state and in aqueous solution, respectively. As shown in Figure S3, at ambient temperature, the free H3L ligand has strong luminescent emissions in the solid state, which exhibits the broad emission peak with a maximum at 445 nm (λex = 370 nm), while its emission spectrum in water solutions is at 374 nm. For the H3L ligand the strong fluorescent emissions can be ascribed to large aromatic terphenyl chromospheres, and the observed strong emission bands can be assigned as π–π* transition. In comparison with that of free H3L ligand, upon excitation at 370 nm, the 3D metal–organic framework 1 exhibits strong emission bands with a maximum around 410 nm. On the other hand, when the crystalline materials were ground into powder samples and suspended in the water solutions, 1 exhibits a strong luminescent emission peak with maximum at 374 nm upon excitation at 340 nm, which can be assigned to the luminescence from intraligand emission because similar luminescent bands can be observed for the free H3L ligand in the water solutions.
